Answer: The Chinese and Koreans do it often. If you look at Korea you can see their kpop music is a complete mix of modern backup dancing, singing, rapping, gq style, movie set design, and a super bowl commercial level video production. It reverse engineered everything that’s impactful and valuable and shoved it into one and did it to their extreme engaging style. I would say it’s improved.The Chinese reverse engineered everything and research everything. Then does the same as the Koreans. Look at relevant examples that were effective for a different product or occuring in nature, and see what insightThe Chinese and Koreans do it often. If you look at Korea you can see their kpop music is a complete mix of modern backup dancing, singing, rapping, gq style, movie set design, and a super bowl commercial level video production. It reverse engineered everything that’s impactful and valuable and shoved it into one and did it to their extreme engaging style. I would say it’s improved.The Chinese reverse engineered everything and research everything. Then does the same as the Koreans. Look at relevant examples that were effective for a different product or occuring in nature, and see what insights they gain to implement a new feature into their product. Chinese and Koreans utilize integrated strategy. Figure out the best things to implement. And, do it with great results, and relatively low costs(mostly because they need less r&d because they researched it, or they reverse engineered it and it saved r&d). An example of Chinese product that did this was Tik tok seeing what musically did, and making it easier for anyone to make good content, and to get their content seen. They took an existing idea and saw how it could be copied and improved. The Nio cars from China also did great in cost effectively, and cost efficiently figured out how to get German like quality. Mostly from 50/50 weight distribution, low centre of gravity(easy with battery packs), well optimized suspensions, steering, and well developed (good power curve) motor.In summary, the Chinese and Koreans look at what to copy, and how to tweak what they copied to be a impactful feature in their product. Or, looking at other’s components(motors, steering, suspension) and figuring out insights to how to engineer theirs to higher results(saving some time and costs by figuring out the secret insights).In conclusion, the premium and luxury companies can win against the Chinese companies. A North Face clothing company has a unique brand that is developed. In-house teams that are developed. Components and features need to be unique to the brand so it’s more valuable to that brand. That North Face comfort and oversized style is seen as only looking right for their brand. That brand is theirs. That brand visibility is theirs. Their customer base is theirs. Their features make more impact for them.In short, a companies uniqueness can’t be easily copied or used without being seen as a mockery. (unique brand, unique product, unique features, unique competency/specialization.

Answer: Let me tell you a story:In 1986 I went across China, from Beijing to Urumqi, Turpan, and Kashgar. On the way I stopped off in DaTong, on a mission to find an American guy who had moved there (turns out he had already left China— but that’s not relevant to the story).On the train I met a young PLA soldier who spoke pretty good English. He was traveling home for the first time in over a year, and hadn’t been in contact with his family all that time. It would have been reasonable had he simply said goodbye to me at the station and went on his way, but instead he took me to his home. His mother crLet me tell you a story:In 1986 I went across China, from Beijing to Urumqi, Turpan, and Kashgar. On the way I stopped off in DaTong, on a mission to find an American guy who had moved there (turns out he had already left China— but that’s not relevant to the story).On the train I met a young PLA soldier who spoke pretty good English. He was traveling home for the first time in over a year, and hadn’t been in contact with his family all that time. It would have been reasonable had he simply said goodbye to me at the station and went on his way, but instead he took me to his home. His mother cried when she saw her son and rushed out to buy meat, fish and other really expensive things. This was a coal mining family, with one room, and everyone heating and sleeping on top of the oneOf course I was too ignorant to be embarrassed about this lavish treatment.Then after dinner, instead of sitting around reconnecting with his family, he helped me find people back in town who might help me with my mission.My opinion of China and the Chinese? After over 30 years I’m still here, and still have a warm feeling when I think about that special dinner with the DaTong coal miners.

Answer: I would certainly hope not!I think the Chinese government represents something quite intimidating to the world.When you say hate, I think for many it is fear. Fear of Chinese becoming the global dominant superpower and what that could mean to the freedoms of the western world. I still argue that many of those freedoms are internally in conflict but that’s a much much much wider subject that would take an enormous amount of time to unpack.What I would like to say is this. Fear/hatred of the Chinese government is somewhat understandable.BUTI would urge people to look to the human aspect. To theI would certainly hope not!I think the Chinese government represents something quite intimidating to the world.When you say hate, I think for many it is fear. Fear of Chinese becoming the global dominant superpower and what that could mean to the freedoms of the western world. I still argue that many of those freedoms are internally in conflict but that’s a much much much wider subject that would take an enormous amount of time to unpack.What I would like to say is this. Fear/hatred of the Chinese government is somewhat understandable.BUTI would urge people to look to the human aspect. To the people of China. Who in my experience of living here for a long time are incredibly warm, kind, loving and pragmatic. I love my life in China. My wife, my children, friends, and extended family are the most incredible people.On many occasions, I have had people on the street share their umbrella with me when I was caught in the rain. I’ve had people escort me to a subway gate when I got lost.Another deep cultural aspect in China is the term “guanxi 关系” very loosely translated to “relationship”, is the foundation of society. It’s a form of accepted societal tradition that pushes us to build bonds with each other and do each other favours to build that relationship. Once a bond is formed that is like family, and we help each other out from time to time as if we are family. That can be seen negatively, like a quid pro quo perhaps. but I think it’s a lot better than the “dog eat dog” ethos. It emphasizes success through bonds formed. Isn’t that a great thing? And I’ll tell you from personal experience, these bonds, are not fake bonds. They develop into deep and meaningful relationships based on trust and helping one another.I’ve never been to a country where the people are more actively friendly than China. I feel extremely privileged to live here.So in answer to your question. Perhaps yes, perhaps a lot of people do hate China. But I don’t think they should and I imagine most of those people have never been here.I think as with any human life, we should look to individuals, cultures, traditions, and just the beauty in everyday life where people are kind and helpful to each other.
